text: A spacious 2nd floor of faux paint and crushed sea shells A TV REMOTE with a shit-ton of buttons. Behind it, a FLAT SCREEN squawks to an empty room. A SNACK PLATE and EMPTY CUP sit atop a kitchen island. PUSHING PAST a BIN of CHILDREN’S TOYS, down a hallway fil with STEAM...

THE STEAM swirls around the spa-like interior. A PLASTIC COMB rests between HIS AND HER SINKS, under EMP TOWEL RACKS. Buried within the aquatic echo-chamber, FAINT CRUNCHING. The faucet SQUEAKS OFF. DRIPS resonate from behind the shower curtain. Through a cracked window, an OCEAN BREEZE swallows the steam. A CAR STEREO attacks and decays. Then quiet. The shower SQUEAKS ON and the STEAM retakes the room. ANOTHER NOISE. The water SQUEAKS OFF and the shower curta yanks back, revealing a BEARDED MAN (36) with sun-baked s alarmed but motionless. Muffled, through walls: TIRES ON GRAVEL. THE THUMP OF CAR DOORS. ON THE BEARDED MAN: FIGHT-OR-FLIGHT...
A FAMILY spills through the door (FATHER, MOTHER, weighed down with GROCERIES and TWO YOUNG DAUGHTERS running wild) wonderful cacophony disrupting the quiet.
The FATHER places REALTOR’S HOUSE KEYS on the island coun beside the SNACK PLATE...
Hey! QUIET...  The WIFE turns from the THERMOSTAT and hushes the kids. The TV IS AUDIBLE. The Father sidesteps into the hallway, seeing DISSIPATING STEAM DRIFT FROM THE BATHROOM.
Honey. AMANDA. Take them back to the car. Call 911. The Wife corrals the girls as the Father DRAWS FROM A WOO KNIFE BLOCK SET, creeping down the hallway...
(urgent whisper) Eric! What are you doing?
(bluffing a threat)

There’s a dog?! Nearing the bathroom threshold, the Father tightens a two handed grip around his weapon, realizing he’s selected a ROUNDED STEEL SHARPENER from the knife block. HE SLIPS TO THE HARD WOOD FLOOR, landing torso upright wi SHARP BREATH. A Daughter breaks free as the Mother fumbles her purse. The Father’s lower vantage reveals A TRAIL OF WET FOOTPRI LEADING TO THE BACK OF THE HOUSE. His daughter runs past GIGGLING, following the footprints
ELLA! NO! Dammit...
Her Father in pursuit, the Daughter crosses the carpeted and pokes her head through an open window.
FROM ABOVE: The Bearded Man runs naked clutching a wad of clothes, disappearing into an alleyway.  10 ON THE WINDOW: The daughter watches nonchalantly until he father scoops her up.

Obscured through CLOTHESLINES and fencing, the Bearded Ma jogs to a stop and steps into his worn khakis. CLACK. He squats and rises, inspecting his PLASTIC COMB, now speckled with sand. He blows it clean.
Dressed but damp, the Bearded Man drips a trail up the sa walkway, anxiously combing his hair. He moves against bea traffic past modern condos, older bungalows and monstrous resort homes.
The Bearded Man sheaths his comb and turns down a walkway leading to a SMALL TOWN POLICE STATION.
The Bearded Man opens the door for an exiting PATROL OFFI returning a nod and weaving his way past RECEPTION to a FEMALE OFFICER (55) eating an egg sandwich at her desk.
If you get any calls about 104 St. Louis... She looks up from her desk, chewing.
-..it was me.

Good morning... He fails to read her expectant look. FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) (relenting) I think I just heard that go out. She motions to a nearby DISPATCHER who removes his HEADSE  FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) Dale, who picked up the ten- fourteen?
Maucieri and Lutz. She picks a WALKIE TALKIE from her desk, waving it.
May I?
(replacing headset) Yes ma'am.
(into walkie) County five one nine? She deadpans the Bearded Man. He returns an anxious stare
Go for county five one nine.
Make that ten fourteen on St. Louis a ten-thirty-one. Repeat, ten- thirty-one, same address.
Roger. She sets the walkie down and gestures to the untouched ha of her sandwich. The Bearded Man shakes ‘no’.
Is there anything I should do? There was a kid. Kids.
Sure, hon- not do it again.
Use houses or get busted?

One would take care of the other, wouldn't it? Next time, you’1ll be processed. He nods. She returns to her sandwich.  11 12 13 14 FEMALE OFFICER (CONT’D) And I‘’d worry more about the realtor. Those places go for three thousand a week. (bites, chews) Four.
The Bearded Man stands curbside, gazing vulnerably into RUSHING TRAFFIC.

LOOKING TOWARDS THE OCEAN, a CROWDED stretch of beach. The Bearded Man hunches into a foreground SILHOUETTE, settling under the shade of the boardwalk. Foot traffic CLUNKS above as he observes the bustle. A TOSSED FOOD CARTON lands in the nearby sand. He looks u SEAGULLS HOVER ABOVE, aggressively competing for scraps. THE SOUNDSCAPE FUSES INTO WHITE NOISE.
THE WIND WHIPS across the now desolate beach. An older couple scan the shore with a METAL DETECTOR. The Bearded Man collects RECYCLABLES, placing them in an oversized canvas bag.

The Bearded Man drags the bag through reeds and coarse gr He digs into his shirt collar and lifts a BALL BEARING NECKLACE over his head. Threaded through the necklace, a set of CAR KEYS. He unlocks the trunk of a BLUE FOUR-DOOR 1990 PONTIAC BONNEVILLE, in disrepair and weathered by the sun. He heaves the recyclables into the trunk and latches it.  15 16 17 18 19

The Bearded Man opens the driver’s side doors, throwing l onto stacks of neatly folded clothes, books and supplies. pillow and sheets line the back seat. He pulls out BOOTS and throws a SATCHEL over his shoulder FROM THE FRONT OF THE VEHICLE, chipped paint and rust surround BULLET HOLES grouped by the windshield frame.
FROZEN CUSTARD, AMUSEMENT RIDES and OVERFLOWING GARBAGE C The beachfront shops cash-in on an ARMY OF TOURISTS.

The BOARDWALK DIN carries to a hotel service entrance. Th Bearded Man expertly sifts through a DUMPSTER. He wipes grease off a ‘FUNLAND’ TICKET BOOK and tucks it away. He rescues a FATTY CUT OF MEAT from a nest of foil. Openi his satchel, he reveals a FOOD-PREP KIT WITH MISMATCHED COOKING UTENSILS AND CONTAINERS. He places the meat in Tupperware, adding a homemade marin before sealing the lid.
ON A TIN PLATE: STEAK BONES sucked clean. The Bearded Man wraps a RAG around the handle of a dented CAMPING KETTLE and pulls it from a COOKING FIRE. He pours BOILING WATER into a CUP.

WIND through reeds, crashing WAVES, and CHIRPING Crickets The Bearded Man reclines in the back, sipping tea and rea under a solar garden lamp hung from sagging upholstery. His eyes drift from the page. He slides the ‘FUNLAND’ TIC into the crease and closes the book. FROM OUTSIDE, the lamp dims to black.  20 21 22 23 24 25 26
THROUGH A LONG LENS: Distorted by rising heat from the crowded boardwalk planks, the Bearded Man offers somethin his hand to several PASSERS-BY. He is ignored.

ON THE ‘FUNLAND’ TICKETS: six are ripped from the book. A TICKET-TAKER seats the Bearded Man in a suspended track ride-car and secures the lap bar. The ride-car lurches forward and up through hydraulic HAU MANSION DOORS with a BLAST OF PIPE ORGAN MUSIC...
The Bearded Man RUMBLES PAST A MIRROR MAZE, BOBBING SKULL HOWLING WEREWOLVES, A MISTY GRAVEYARD... A STROBE flashes.

THE EXIT DOORS HISS OPEN: The Bearded Man squirms from th ride-car before the ATTENDANT can lift the lap bar. A GHOULISH LAUGH through crackling speakers. EXT. ‘WHAC-A-MOLE’ BOOTH - FUNLAND - AFTERNOON 24 The Bearded Man SLAPS the ticket book on the counter of a WHAC-A-MOLE amusement game. A LUCKY KID snatches it up.
The Bearded Man CASTS A ROD AND REEL from the surf, his SATCHEL over his shoulder.
By the light of a MAKESHIFT HEAD-LAMP, the Bearded Man FILLETS A BLUEFISH with a CORK HANDLED FISHING KNIFE.  27 28 29 30
‘O-Dark-thirty’. A COMPACT CAR drifts by upscale homes, tossing out NEWSPAPERS.

Cast in deep blue light diffused through dew-covered wind the Bearded man lies curled in the back seat. TIRES CREEPING ACROSS SANDY ASPHALT. THROUGH THE DRIVER'S SIDE WINDOW, abstracted by moisture, POLICE LIGHTS roll in. A CAR DOOR opens and shuts. A BLUR FIGURE approaches the Bonneville and KNOCKS. The Bearded Man rises, waiting with blinking eyes.
It's officer Eddy. He flips the lock and pushes the door open for OFFICER ED the Female Officer from the police station.
I'd like you to come in to the station.
Is this about the house? I coul-
Dwight, sweetheart, I’1l explain. Just come with me.
The Bearded Man, DWIGHT, stews in the back of the cruiser FLASHING THE CRUISER’S TURRET, Officer Eddy coasts throug red light and turns off the road.
How ‘bout some breakfast?
The cruiser rolls under a canopy up to a DRIVE-THRU WINDO The SPEAKER CRACKLES.  31 32

A SKELETON CREW works to the HUM of vending machines and few SLURRED OUTBURSTS from the drunk tank. Officer Eddy guides Dwight past empty desks and down a hallway, carrying a TAKE-OUT BAG and NEWSPAPER.
Officer Eddy seats Dwight at a kitchenette table and pull boxed food from the bag.
I apologize for the mystery- I don’t mean to scare you. You’re not in any trouble, everything’s fine- She winces into a solemn, regretful grin. Dwight settles his seat as she takes hers.

-you'll be fine. Oh, see, I just don’t know exactly how to handle this. And I know I’m not to bring this up- but, honey, someone brought this to our stoop. (unfolding the newspaper) I just thought you should be somewhere safe when you found out. Dwight suppresses a rush of realization.
With somebody... She slides the newspaper across the table. He pulls it cl without laying eyes on it. His attention shifts to a WALL CALENDAR hanging behind her.

He’s going to be released. I’m not sure how much you... I just need you to know that you’re safe and that you can let me know whatever you need. They are missed. It’s an awful thing he did to them. I’m just going to hold you here for a little bit, let you breathe And who knows? This might even be an opportunity... HER VOICE WASHES INTO CARDIOVASCULAR PULSING. DWIGHT’S FACE GOES SLACK.  33 34 35 36 37 38 10.

Dwight takes the center of a residential street, moving numbly through pools of orange light, the NEWSPAPER in ha COLLEGE KIDS watch him from a outdoor hot tub. Their mout are moving, but Dwight hears no voices.
Dwight takes a solitary swim in the Atlantic. And goes under for a long time... EXT. SUPERMARKET —- MORNING 35 Aluminum and glass CLANK into a self-serve RECYCLING MACH
Dwight hands a RECEIPT to a CASHIER and sets a ‘DE, MD, V ROAD MAP on the counter. He looks half-dead.

Dwight pops the lid off a rusted coffee can from his trun He adds a handful of SMALL BILLS to the modest stash. He pulls out a GAS CANISTER and sets it down. ..-opens the driver's side door, pops the gas and the hoo .-.-Shakes the canister, empties it into the tank. ..-walks an 8” cube wrapped in plastic bags from the trun the hood. .»»-peels away the plastic bags, revealing a CAR BATTERY. .+-props the hood open, sets the battery in the tray and secures the connections.
Dwight places the map on the seat and turns the engine ov Beside the map is THE NEWSPAPER. An article is titled: ‘9 PLEA DEAL MANDATES VA DOUBLE MURDERER FREED.  39 40 4l 42 11.
HALF-FLAT FRONT TIRES roll back, breaking free of overgro grass. The car reverses out of the sandy lot onto the str
A general store with a fueling station. Dwight presses a HISSING AIR HOSE to a tire, behind him a display of color rafts and floatation devices. He moves to the next tire.

HAND GUNS LAID ON VELVET, behind thick glass. TAGS tied t the trigger guards are marked from $180-$700. Dwight thumbs his cash and pockets it, surveying the shop florescent lights, drop ceiling and linoleum. He drifts a the gun displays, spotting HIMSELF ON A SURVEILLANCE MONI atop a stack of VHS DECKS. He locates the security camera turns to the WOMAN behind the register. She glances under the counter and stares back hard. Dwight approaches. She steps closer to the counter. He stops at the register and spins a CAROUSEL OF POSTCARD
Do you sell stamps?
I do. But those ones have postage included.
CLOSE-UP, POSTCARD: OUT OF FOCUS TEXT, a BALLPOINT PEN ho above in contemplation... In crude script: ‘Your brother,’
The Bonneville idles beside a MAILBOX. Dwight signs his n and deposits the postcard.  43 44 45 12.
Dwight drives a two lane highway bordered by corn fields metal framed irrigation equipment.
CICADAS drown out THUMPING LIVE MUSIC. Dwight watches HEADLIGHTS SWEEP BY before exiting the car.

A jumbo shack-themed bar for half-assed bikers. Dim light from the facade casts a warm edge onto the VEHICLES in th lot. Dwight walks along the cars, inspecting their conten He tries a car door- LOCKED. He tries the next- UNLOCKED- and rummages inside, thrown by the OVERHEAD INTERIOR LIGHT. Nothing. Another UNLOCKED DOOR. He SWITCHES OFF the interior light before searching. Nothing again. Cupping glass, Dwight checks the cab of a locked PICKUP TRUCK. He moves to ANOTHER TRUCK a few spots down with a ‘NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF RIFLE OWNERS’ WINDOW DECAL. He spies something on the cab’s floor, angling his head f better view. He circles around and tries the other door- LOCKED... AND A LOUD FUCKING ALARM. Dwight flees, nearly tripping over a ROCK- he snatches it does an about face and SMASHES it through the cab window. He reaches through the jagged glass and unlatches the doo pulling a SMALL PLASTIC CASE from under the seat. THE LIVE MUSIC SURGES as a COWBOY exits the bar holding a CUP, wresting his keys from his tight jeans. Dwight dives behind his car, panicking across the dirt. The COWBOY aims his keys at the BLARING truck. TWO QUICK HONKS and the ALARM IS SILENCED. The Cowboy hea back inside with a BELCH.  46 47 48 49 50 51 13.

Dwight rolls up his window. DUST SETTLES as he checks the rear view and opens the case beside him: BINGO- A SNUB-NO REVOLVER fitted in foam with SIX .357 CARTRIDGES. He lifts the weapon, noticing a HEAVY DUTY TRIGGER LOCK.

MUTED, RHYTHMIC CRACKING ECHOES through the river valley. The Bonneville is parked alone in the lot, below tall tre and rock formations. WATER RUSHES nearby. There’s a small PLAQUE for tourists, a rustic TRASH BIN and PORTA-POTTIES

Dwight SMASHES THE REVOLVER’S TRIGGER LOCK WITH A TIRE IR He assesses the damage- very little. He places the gun on rock and pounds with more and more might and less and les control, following it with wild swings into the dirt. THWAP, THWAP, CRUNK. The metal gives. He dusts off the gu it’s broken in several places, the TRIGGER LOCK STILL INT

TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, marching in disappointment towards trash bin. He watches a HYBRID SUV pull in with a half- hearted smile and nod. He discretely deposits the broken gun, returning to the Bonneville as the SUV DRIVER (40), fit and wearing fleece hops out with a LEASH and a LATTE. A DOG BARKS from the SUV as Dwight pulls out.
The Bonneville weaves between eastern foot-hills.
A shadowed ROAD SIGN against a waning blue sky. HEADLIGHTS illuminate it: ‘PRISON AREA: HITCHHIKING PROHIBITED’  52 53 54 55 56 57 14.
Soft morning light. Dwight sits with predatory stillness.
The Bonneville is parked a few rows from the lot’s edge w a view of the prison gate. Rising behind it is high fenci razor wire and concrete.
Midday sun beams into the car. The PATTER OF LIQUID FLOWING INTO PLASTIC. Dwight is hunc in his seat, eyes to his lap.
LOW ANGLE OF TIRES AND GRAVEL, the prison visible between ground and the car chassis: the driver's side door opens urine pours from a plastic bottle onto the gravel. A large sedan pulls into the lot.
Dwight tugs his door closed, observing THROUGH THE

An early ‘90s model WHITE STRETCH LIMOUSINE parks in the closest to the prison gates. ON THE DOOR: ‘CLELAND LIMOUS From the far side, A MAN and a WOMAN step out for cigaret the engine idling. Dwight half turns the keys in the ignition and rolls down passenger side window. Their VOICES compete with MUSIC emanating from the limous their smoke puffs drift into the wind. Dwight pulls his satchel from the floor and rests it on t passenger’s seat.
LOUDER MUSIC and LAUGHTER from behind the closed doors of limousine. Dwight’s Bonneville hasn’t moved.  58 59 60 15.

Dwight squints at the prison entrance. An INMATE (42, whi male) is being escorted out by a CORRECTIONS OFFICER. The inmate struts in prison issued slacks and shirt, carrying cardboard BOX. He’s tattooed up his arms and neck, strong with a gut. Dwight is frozen. THE FAMILY exits the limousine with a brief BLAST OF MUSI The TEDDY (45), stocky in casual preppie attire, hops bac inside the driver’s seat to lower the volume. There’s CARL(39), wiry and tattooed in baggy clothes, CHR (46), scornful with teased, dirty blond hair, and HOPE (4 tight pony-tail and a dark, chiseled face. A BOY (14), lanky with hand-me-down clothes, scoots to th edge of the back seat, slouched over a HAND-HELD VIDEOGAM CONSOLE. The corrections officer hands the inmate a white envelope heads back with PARTING WORDS. The Family Members circle Inmate. Chris motions for the Boy to greet the Inmate, but he refuses. She power-walks over and grabs the Boy around th biceps. He shakes her off, retreating into the car as she palms his chin and shoves it back. They all pile back in the limousine. Dwight starts his car.

head_text.subj: ON THE REAR OF THE SPEEDING LIMOUSINE, FROM THE HOOD OF T

text: BONNEVILLE, several car lengths back. CHRIS rises from the SUNROOF with a PLASTIC CUP in hand. flinches as airborne debris blows into her eye, the cup g flying as she awkwardly ducks below.
The cup CLACKS PAST Dwight’s vibrating car. He checks the speedometer. They're averaging 83 MPH.  61 62 63 64 65 16.
The limousine pulls into the dirt lot of a single story stucco bar. The only other vehicle is a TRUCK FOR SALE. The Bonneville whips past, maintaining course.

Watching his rearview, Dwight slows to a stop on the shoulder. P.O.V. (DWIGHT): HOPE yanks up a metal entrance gate, a PADLOCK in her hand. The Family follows her into the bar. ON DWIGHT as he rolls out into a wide U-turn.
Dwight pulls the Bonneville up a grassy incline beside th limousine and cuts the engine.
Dwight has a look around the car cabin and UNZIPS the satchel. He slides SOMETHING into his pant pocket. He closes his eyes. Then yanks the keys.

Dwight steps from the Bonneville, looping his key chain around his neck and tucking it into his shirt. TRACKING WITH DWIGHT as he shuts the door and walks unsteadily around the side of the building. A SOUND SYSTEM inside the bar cycles through RADIO STATIO Muffled, celebratory VOICES lure Dwight towards the back. He tries a side door near a dumpster. Locked. A DOOR SPRING. A WOMAN'S VOICE. A CLINKING CHAIN. Dwight follows the wall towards the sound, peeking one ey beyond the edge of the building. Hope is crouched by the rear entrance, opening cellar doo as the Teddy rolls a BEER KEG from a gated cold-storage u  66 67 17. Dwight rotates out of sight, his back to the wall.
Stop breathing out your mouth.

Yeah, if you stop talking out your ass. Putting him on your books- they’1l be looking at you if he fucks up even once- and it won’t be on me... Dwight TUNES OUT, drawn to a DISTANT RUMBLE above. IN THE SKY: a drifting contrail in the wake of a jet... The cellar doors swing SHUT. Dwight pivots around the corner- they’re gone. He slips inside the back door.

From bright daylight into a black cave. AUTO-TUNED RAP SWELLS as Dwight navigates the memorabilia lined hallway, his eyes adjusting to the darkness. TRACKING BEHIND DWIGHT, as he reaches in his pocket and p out the CORK HANDLED FISHING KNIFE. He passes the kitchen, steadying himself against the wall nearly knocking off a framed picture. He presses his hand a door and it swings open...

It’s a cramped, dingy-tiled bathroom bisected by a narrow walkway. On one wall: two stalls and a trash can. On the other: two urinals and a stickered-up mirror mounted abov porcelain sink. Dwight crosses the walkway and turns to face the door. He adjusts the blade in his hand. The MUSIC lowers, then blasts LOUDER. ON DWIGHT, inching towards the door- VOICES from just bey it stop him short.  18. The Convict and Carl push through the door, drinking from plastic cups.
Naw, man- she just talks too much. Shit- I ain’t used to that.
She talks shit, or she just talks too much? IN THE FAR STALL, Dwight stands silent, shadowed.
(jokingly fed up) Motherfucker. The two men place their cups atop the urinals and relieve themselves.
What, me too?
Yeah, maybe just let me piss. Haven’t done it alone with four walls in over a decade.
Ha, dude. They share a bit of a laugh then urinate in silence. Carl Finishes up and ZIPS. CARL (CONT’D) Hey, man. You all right?
Got some shit lined up. Favors. Carl walks to the door. CONVICT (CONT’D) You ain’t gonna wash up?
Naw, man, I don’t piss on my hands. (walking out) You want another one? Or you want beer?
All that shit...  19.

I hear that. The door swings shut behind Carl. The Convict lets out a deep breath, passes some gas. He zips up, his face expressionless as he steps to the si across from the far stall. Dwight is three feet from the Convict, DIRECTLY BEHIND HIM. The Convict pumps soap, scrubs his hands. INSIDE THE STALL, Dwight watches, sweaty, seething. ON THE FISHING KNIFE, Dwight nervously auditions hand gri ON DWIGHT’S contorting face. The MUSIC IS LOUD. The convict splashes his face and inspects his pores in t mirror- his jaw tenses as his EYES LOCK ON A REFLECTION I THE STALL BEHIND HIM. Counterbalanced by fear and rage, Dwight’s thrust is almo lethargic. The Convict whirls around as the stall door pu open- DWIGHT SWINGS THE FISHING KNIFE, CUTTING A DEEP SLI INTO THE BACK OF THE CONVICT’S NECK. The Convict fails to register the wound and rushes Dwight grabbing him by the throat with jailhouse power, forcing against the stall.

IN THE MIRROR BEHIND THEM, we see the severity of the Convict’s wound, LIKE A BLOODY GILL, AS IT RAPIDLY OVERFL WITH DARK RED FLUID. Dwight gasps in the Convict’s two-handed clench, flailing WEAKLY JABBING THE KNIFE INTO THE CONVICTS RIBS. CONVICT (CONT’D) C'MON, LET’S...

head_text.subj: DWIGHT RAISES THE FISHING KNIFE AND THRUSTS IT DOWNWARD I

text: THE CONVICT’S SKULL. The Convict lets out an open-mouthed GRUNT, the KNIFE PLANTED IN THE TOP OF HIS HEAD. Enraged, with shock setting in, the Convict throws Dwight towards the still-running sink, then to the floor. They slip and flail, bathed in blood. Dwight takes a beat until the Convict BLEEDS OUT, clutching Dwight’s shirt.  20. Dwight pushes off with his feet, his SHIRT RIPPING as he disentangles from the Convict, who crumples to the floor, wheezing. He stares at Dwight, a hint of recognition. CONVICT (CONT’D) (quietly) Do I know you? Dwight stares back.
Yes. Dwight ramps into hyperventilation.
He leans over the Convict, YANKS THE KNIFE FROM HIS SKULL
Unhinged, Dwight STABS THE CONVICT REPEATEDLY IN THE CHES Then collapses, completely spent. SOMEONE POUNDS ON THE DOOR.
(muffled, through door) Hurry the fuck up, man! Party’s for you! Dwight crawls to the sink, puts a bloody hand on it and p himself to his feet.
(projecting further away) WHAT? HELL NO! HE’S PROBABLY BEATIN’ OFF. Dwight heaves with pain, resigned. He tosses the knife towards the door.

(through door) Told you we shoulda had a hooker waiting... Two playful SMACKS AGAINST THE DOOR. Dwight’s breathing regulates. Eyes on the door: JUST MUSI  68 69 70 71 21. He turns off the running faucet and retrieves the knife.

TRACKING WITH DWIGHT, COVERED IN BLOOD, swaying into the hallway and heading out the way he came. Behind him, Teddy walks off, oblivious. The RADIO STATION runs an ADVERTISEMENT, the stereo CYCLE THROUGH STATIONS, casual VOICES and LAUGHTER fill the voi until it lands on CLASSIC ROCK. As Dwight exits, the sunlight is blinding.

Dwight treads heavily towards the Bonneville, past the limousine. He turns back and STABS THE LIMOUSINE’S FRONT TIRE, HIS HAND SLIDING DOWN THE BLADE ON IMPACT. He leaves the knife in the FIZZLING tire, HIS HAND DRIPPI BLOOD TOWARDS HIS CAR.
Dwight takes his seat, admiring the DEEP CUT ACROSS HIS FINGERS. He reaches into his collar, feels around his nec NO KEYS.
DWIGHT’S CAR KEYS ON THE BATHROOM FLOOR, the broken ball- bearing necklace threaded through. CLASSIC ROCK ECHOES.
(muffled, through door) Let’s go, brother. Coming in... In the background, the door swings in and impacts the Convict’s body, sliding it a few inches on the wet tile.
WHISTLING WIND and QUIET ROCK. ON THE STABBED TIRE, as Dwight shuffles past. He rounds the limousine hood and tries the driver’s side UNLOCKED.

Dwight sits and scours for keys- the ignition...the visor digs in a console CUP-HOLDER and pulls out a set, turning them in the ignition as the bar door opens. LOUD, OFFENSIVE MUSIC emanates from the limousine’s stere Dwight shifts and hits the gas.

ON THE STABBED TIRE, as it WHIRLS THE KNIFE. The limousine carves a wobbly path, kicking up DUST as th Family Members exit, confused, furious, bloody. Hope hold PUMP SHOTGUN. Chris and Carl sprint after the limousine, shouting hysterically.
Dwight’s face quivers with emotion, but he can’t quite cr DOWN THE ROAD, about a quarter mile, there’s a CONCRETE BARRIER along a curve. MUSIC STILL BLASTS. ON THE SPEEDOMETER: from 50MPH to 70MPH.
The shredded tire DISINTEGRATES, only the rim remains, SHRIEKING METAL and SHOWERING SPARKS.

Dwight TURNS OFF THE BLASTING RADIO. Relaxing now, with peace soon upon him, he maxes out the speed of the teetering sedan. HE CLOSES HIS EYES.  78 79 80 23. In the relative quiet, A STEADY THUMPING IS NOW AUDIBLE. Dwight blinks aware, triangulating the source- it’s behin him, in the passenger compartment.
AGAINST THE SOUNDPROOF GLASS, unnerved but composed.

The limousine WHIRS to a stop amidst SMOKE AND DUST. Dwight exits the car, caked in blood, opening the rear-hi passenger door like a zombie chauffeur. The BOY climbs out grasping his video game console, scurr a safe distance before turning to face Dwight. They regard each other. Chris and Carl pant towards them, far in the distance. Dwight pushes the passenger door closed and turns away.
Did you hurt Wade? Dwight turns back, breaths some air.
I did. Wade hurt my parents.
No he didn’t. He just helped out. The boy turns and walks the highway towards his relatives their frantic YELLING LOST IN THE WIND.
The limousine SPARKS past the barrier at sublethal speed.
Dwight hangs in limbo, his adrenaline dumped.
(under his breath) Silly...  81 82 83 84 85 24.

FROM INSIDE THE BONNEVILLE, Family Members congregate aro Dwight’s vehicle. The MAP and the NEWSPAPER flap on the passenger’s seat. LOST IN THE BACKGROUND: Chris YELLS ABUSIVELY at the Boy. Carl burns testosterone with VOWS OF REVENGE. Closer to the Bonneville, inspecting the bullet holes...
Was that the car?
Yep.
You think he was alone?
Do we care?
The limousine CARVES INTO A DITCH AND LANDS HARD. Dwight pops from the door, dismounts the SMOULDERING seda and walks off towards a TREE LINE on the far side of an o field.
Dwight takes cover in the shade of trees.
Dwight DRY HEAVES, nestled between limbs of a fallen oak.
